article.title: GW170817, General Relativistic Magnetohydrodynamic Simulations, and the Neutron Star Maximum Mass

multiple_choice_question.text: What physical phenomenon is depicted in the second column of Figure 1, which is argued to be the most likely origin of GW170817?
choices: A supramassive NS remnant that persists.
A HMNS remnant that undergoes delayed collapse.
A HMNS remnant that undergoes prompt collapse.
The formation of a stable magnetar.
The relationship between the total mass of a binary system and the individual neutron star masses.
The maximum mass of a nonrotating and a uniformly rotating neutron star based on the Rhoades-Ruffini causality argument.
The timescale for the delayed collapse of a HMNS into a black hole.
The critical density above which an EOS needs to be sufficiently stiff to produce a stiff core.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of formula (5) in the context of the article?
choices: It describes the relationship between the mass of the accretion disk and the jet luminosity in sGRBs.
It quantifies the delay time between the merger of two neutron stars and the launch of a sGRB jet.
It combines observational data with theoretical limits to establish a possible range for the maximum mass of a nonrotating neutron star.
It calculates the minimum magnetic field strength required to launch a jet from the poles of a spinning black hole.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main argument presented in the article for a low estimate of the neutron star maximum mass?
choices: The observation of high-energy emissions from the remnant of GW170817 suggests the formation of a stable magnetar, which constrains the maximum mass.
The presence of a sGRB in GW170817, combined with GRMHD simulations, favors a scenario where a HMNS undergoes delayed collapse to form a black hole, implying a lower maximum mass.
The detection of a kilonova associated with GW170817 implies the presence of a massive neutron star remnant, pushing the upper limit on the maximum mass higher.
The analysis of the gravitational wave signal alone provides strong constraints on the equation of state of dense matter, leading to a precise determination of the maximum neutron star mass.
